message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including fever, otitis media, and skin lesions suggest a bacterial infection. The patient's low blood pressure, pale appearance, and capillary refill time suggest sepsis. Defective beta-2 integrin is associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency, which can cause recurrent bacterial infections and impaired wound healing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a bacterial infection with neutrophilia and thrombocytopenia. The white mucosal patches in the oral examination suggest oral thrush, which is common in bacterial infections. The skin lesions suggest eczema, which is common in patients with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) caused by defective beta-2 integrin. Defective IL-2R gamma chain causes X-linked severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), defective NADPH oxidase causes chronic granulomatous disease (CGD), and defective WAS gene causes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS). Therefore, the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms is a defective beta-2 integrin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a possible bacterial infection, which may be due to a defect in the immune system. Beta-2 integrin deficiency causes leukocyte adhesion deficiency syndrome type I, which can manifest with recurrent bacterial infections and delayed wound healing. Defective IL-2R gamma chain causes X-linked severe combined immunodeficiency, which would have presented earlier in life. Defective NADPH oxidase and WAS gene mutations can also cause immunodeficiency, but they do not typically present with recurrent ear infections or skin lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a bacterial infection and the leukocyte count and neutrophil count support this possibility. The presence of white mucosal patches that bleed when scraped off is suggestive of candidiasis, which is common in patients with impaired immune systems. Among the options, only defective beta-2 integrin is associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency syndrome, which causes impaired immune response and recurrent bacterial and fungal infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible case of leukocyte adhesion deficiency syndrome (LAD), which is associated with defective beta-2 integrin. The white mucosal patches also indicate a possible Candida infection, which is common in LAD patients due to impaired leukocyte function. Defective IL-2R gamma chain is associated with T-cell immunodeficiencies, defective NADPH oxidase is associated with chronic granulomatous disease, and WAS gene mutation is associated with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, all of which do not fully match the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including fever, poor feeding, oral thrush, and skin lesions, suggest a possible immunodeficiency. The low blood pressure and pale appearance suggest septic shock. The presence of otitis media and umbilical cord separation suggests possible neonatal sepsis. Among the options, only defective beta-2 integrin can cause leukocytosis with neutrophilia and skin lesions. Other options such as defective IL-2R gamma chain, defective NADPH oxidase, and WAS gene mutation are associated with different types of immunodeficiencies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the ear discharge, skin lesions, and oral mucosal patches, suggest a diagnosis of sepsis. The patient's low blood pressure and elevated white blood cell count indicate that he may have a bacterial infection. The presence of white mucosal patches that bleed when scraped off suggests the possibility of a fungal infection, specifically candidiasis. Among the options, only a defective beta-2 integrin is associated with both bacterial and fungal infections. Therefore, this is the most likely underlying cause of the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including recurrent infections and poor wound healing, suggest a possible immunodeficiency disorder. Among the options, only defective beta-2 integrin is associated with a specific immunodeficiency disorder called leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD). The symptoms of LAD include recurrent bacterial infections, delayed wound healing, and poor growth.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with sepsis, with leukocytosis and low blood pressure. The patient also has ear discharge and white mucosal patches, suggesting a bacterial infection. The skin lesions and low weight percentile may suggest a genetic disorder, but the most likely cause of the sepsis is a bacterial infection, and the most common cause of such infections is neutrophil dysfunction due to a defective beta-2 integrin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including fever, otitis media, poor feeding, skin lesions, and white mucosal patches, suggest a diagnosis of leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) type 1. This is caused by a defect in beta-2 integrin, which is important for leukocyte adhesion and migration. Defective IL-2R gamma chain is associated with X-linked severe combined immunodeficiency, defective NADPH oxidase is associated with chronic granulomatous disease, and WAS gene mutation is associated with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, all of which have different clinical features than LAD type 1.
